title: Parthenope (Siren)
text:
Parthenope (<a href="Ancient%20Greek">Ancient Greek</a>: Παρθενόπη) was one of the <a href="Siren%20%28mythology%29">Sirens</a> in <a href="Greek%20mythology">Greek mythology</a>. Her name means "maiden-voiced" from "parthenos" and "ops".
Family.
Parthenope was the daughter of the <a href="Deity">god</a> <a href="Achelous">Achelous</a> and the <a href="Muse">Muse</a> <a href="Terpsichore">Terpsichore</a>. Her two sisters were called <a href="Ligeia%20%28mythology%29">Ligeia</a>, and <a href="Leucosia%20%28mythology%29">Leucosia</a>.
Mythology.
According to Greek legend, Parthenope cast herself into the sea and <a href="Drowning">drowned</a> when her songs failed to entice <a href="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>. Her body washed ashore at <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, on the island of <a href="Megaride">Megaride</a>, where the <a href="Castel%20dell%27Ovo">Castel dell'Ovo</a> is now located. Her tomb on the island was called "constraction of sirens". When people from the city of <a href="Cumae">Cumae</a> settled there, they named their city <a href="History%20of%20Naples%23Greek%20birth%2C%20Roman%20acquisition">Parthenope</a> in her honour.
A <a href="Roman%20mythology">Roman myth</a> tells a different version of the tale, in which a <a href="centaur">centaur</a> named <a href="Vesuvius">Vesuvius</a> was enamored with Parthenope. Angered, <a href="Jupiter%20%28god%29">Jupiter</a> turned the centaur into <a href="Mount%20Vesuvius">a stratovolcano</a> and Parthenope into the city of <a href="Naples">Naples</a>. Thwarted in his desire, Vesuvius' rage is manifested in the volcano's frequent violent eruptions.
In literature and art.
Parthenope has been depicted in various forms of literature and art, from ancient coins that bore her semblance to the <a href="Fountain%20of%20the%20Spinacorona%2C%20Naples">Fountain of the Spinacorona</a>, where she is depicted quenching the fires of Vesuvius with water from her breasts. In his "<a href="Georgics">Georgics</a>", <a href="Virgil">Virgil</a> stated that he had been nurtured by Parthenope, writing:
In addition, Parthenope has served as the inspiration for a number of other works, such as <a href="Manuel%20de%20Zumaya">Manuel de Zumaya</a>'s "<a href="Partenope%20%28Zumaya%29">Partenope</a>" and the <a href="ancient%20Greek%20novel">ancient Greek novel</a> "<a href="M%C4%93tiokhos%20kai%20Parthenop%C4%93">Mētiokhos kai Parthenopē</a>". Also, several operas based on the myth of Parthenope were composed on the 18th century by <a href="Domenico%20Sarro">Sarro</a> (1722), <a href="Leonardo%20Vinci">Vinci</a> (1725), <a href="George%20Frideric%20Handel">Handel</a> (1730), <a href="Antonio%20Vivaldi">Vivaldi</a> (1738) and <a href="Johann%20Adolph%20Hasse">Hasse</a> (1767).
